content: How can I help you today?

I'm here because my wife thinks we need help, especially with everything going on at home right now. I’m not entirely convinced this will help, but things haven’t been great, and I don’t know what else to do.
It sounds like you’re feeling a bit unsure about this, but also looking for a way to navigate the challenges at home. What’s been happening lately that’s led to this moment?

Our son has been having a lot of behavioral issues—acting out, not listening, and we just don’t know how to help him. It's putting a huge strain on my relationship with my wife, and on top of that, I can’t focus at work or enjoy anything outside of it. It feels like everything is falling apart.

It sounds like you’re under a lot of pressure right now—with your son’s challenges, the tension with your wife, and even feeling disconnected from work and the things you usually enjoy. That can be overwhelming. What’s been most difficult for you in all of this?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I’m failing—failing as a parent, failing as a husband. I want to be there for my son, my wife, and even my daughter, but I don’t know how to fix anything, and it feels like everything I try just makes things worse.

It sounds like you really want to be the kind of parent and partner who supports your family, but right now you’re feeling stuck and unsure of how to make things better. That’s a heavy weight to carry. What do you think would help lighten some of that weight or make things feel a little less overwhelming?

I honestly don’t know. I feel like I’ve tried everything I can think of, and I’m just out of ideas. Maybe someone else helping us figure out how to help my son would take some of the pressure off, but I’ve never done anything like this before. It’s hard to know where to even start.

It sounds like you’ve really been trying your best, even though it hasn’t felt like enough. Reaching out for support can be a big step, especially when it’s new territory. It’s clear that you care deeply about your family. What would it mean to you if you could find a way forward and feel more confident about helping your son and your family?

I think it would mean everything to me. If I could actually help my son and get our family back on track, it would feel like I’m not failing them anymore. I just want us to feel happy and connected again, but I’m scared I won’t be able to make that happen.

That hope for happiness and connection really speaks to how much you care about your family. It also shows how important it is to you to be able to turn things around for everyone. Feeling doubt and fear while holding onto that hope is tough, but it’s brave to even think about where you want to go from here. What would you want to focus on first, if moving toward that happier, more connected family felt possible?

I guess I’d want to start with my son—figuring out what’s really going on with him and how we can help. If we could make progress there, maybe it would help with some of the tension between me and my wife, and I could feel like I’m actually doing something right.

Focusing on your son sounds like a meaningful first step, and you’re thinking about how that could create positive changes for your whole family. It seems like you’re ready to explore ways to better understand his needs and support him. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before we start looking at how you might approach that?
I think that’s really it for now. I just want to figure out how to help him and start fixing what’s broken.

Thank you for sharing that—it’s clear how much your family means to you, and it’s encouraging that you’re ready to take steps to better understand and support your son. To summarize, you’ve shared that your family’s challenges, particularly with your son, have been weighing heavily on you, and you’re hoping to create a happier, more connected home by focusing on him first. Would you like to explore some ways to begin addressing what’s going on with your son?

Thank you for being so honest—it’s clear that you deeply care about your family. Let’s start by exploring what might be driving your son’s behavior and consider ways you can support him. Can you tell me a bit more about what he’s been struggling with or what you've noticed?
Certainly, let’s take a closer look together. What are some of the specific behaviors or situations with your son that have been most challenging or concerning for you?

He’s been really angry and defiant lately. He throws tantrums over the smallest things and doesn’t listen to anything we say. At school, the teachers have mentioned he has trouble following rules and is disruptive in class. It’s like he’s constantly testing limits, and we don’t know how to handle it anymore.

It sounds like your son’s anger and defiance, both at home and at school, have been really challenging to navigate—and figuring out how to respond in a way that helps him hasn’t been easy. It might feel frustrating and concerning to see him struggle so much. What do you think might be driving these behaviors, or have you noticed anything that tends to trigger them?

It seems like his tantrums usually happen when we set boundaries or say no to something he wants. And at school, I think he gets frustrated if things don't go his way or if he doesn't understand something. I don’t know if it’s just a phase he’s going through or if there’s something deeper that we’re missing.

It sounds like those moments of frustration—whether at home with boundaries or at school when things don’t go his way—might be particularly tough for him to manage right now. You're wondering if it's just a normal stage of development or if there’s something more beneath the surface. It’s clear that you want to understand him better. What do you think would help your son feel supported during those challenging moments?
